file_content.text: Sessar? Madoon, come in! Is anyone there? Blast!
I can't thank you enough. Fifty-one's spreading the word, and pretty soon all the guards will know how to stop the Rattataki.
I've studied the jungle noise and found a number of non-indigenous bird calls that increase before an attack.
The Rattataki are imitating bird calls?
My programming enables me to replicate these calls. I can teach the remaining guards to recognize them.
Get right on that, Fifty-one. Thanks for protecting him out there--with this info, we can finally avoid their attacks.
It'll be nice to see the Rattataki on the defensive.
Time to turn the tables.
I'll say. Thanks for everything. We couldn't have cracked their codes without your help.
It's not that big a deal.
You've helped even the playing field in this sector. I think that deserves some recognition.
We'll be a lot safer knowing when the Rattataki are going to attack. Thank you.
Thanks for wasting my skills.
I don't care if you're offended or not. We're safer. That's all that matters to me.
How's it going out there? Getting the information you need?
How do you fight a ghost, Master Jedi?
Major, I've never faced a foe this crafty before.
By now, the Rattataki prisoners control more guard towers than we do; they certainly control the jungle.
Your people are armed and trained. How are prisoners gaining the upper hand?
How can they overcome guards?
The Rattataki are fearsome hunters--and twice as deadly now that they're free.
I've been around, but I've never heard of the Rattataki before.
I don't know the Rattataki.
They're white as death, and nearly as quiet. The Rattataki were the most vicious of the prisoners, and getting free only whet their appetite.
So... tell your superiors?
Look around. The Rattataki are killing guards left, right and center, and you're the only one still standing.
The worst are called the Blood of Talath. They've turned the jungle into a slaughterhouse. Traps are everywhere.
They're communicating somehow--they spring, fall back and regroup with military precision. But they don't have comms or computers.
We need to figure out how they're operating.
Communications can be broken.
I was thinking the same thing. Let me introduce you to someone. Fifty-one? Come over here.
They have to be getting the information from somewhere.
Sounds like you've got a leak.
There's no mole--there's no one left to squeal. It's like they figured out we're there and gathered an army to fight back.
They sound pretty nasty.
They're great at parties--assuming you want the guests brutally murdered.
Look, if we can figure out how they're talking, I have an idea how we can disrupt it. Fifty-one? Come over here.
Greetings, I am C-5D1. Officer Serik believes I can uncover how the Rattataki communicate.
Protocol droid--built to translate new languages, right? Give him enough time in the jungle, he'll hear whatever we're missing.
Problem is, the Rattataki are going to be suspicious of random droids. He won't last thirty seconds unescorted. Any chance you could help?
He will be safe with me, I assure you.
I can escort your droid.
The Force will protect us from their attacks.
I can escort your droid.
If he can follow orders, I'll keep him safe.
I can escort your droid.
I've got a knack for slipping things past blockades, or so I'm told.
I can escort your droid.
Great. Just keep the Rattataki off of Fifty-one, and he'll let you know when he's ready to go.
Will it take long to break their communications code?
How much time will he need?
Not sure. Fifty-one will let you know when he's got all the data he needs. When he's done, get him back here safely.
I'll also need to listen from several points within the jungle, to rule out ambient sounds. I apologize for the trouble.
Don't get in too deep--we've lost enough people already.
You're kidding. [Refuse quest]
I should have known better. We were self-reliant before the Sith showed up, so getting by without you is no problem.
I still haven't heard back from a patrol I sent out this morning. Tell me if you see anything out there, will you?
